profiles: Summary I see myself as someone who wants their work to positively impact as many community members as possible. If i'm not the expert on a given topic, I try to outreach to those who are for and get them involved. The more people with diverse expertise that are working together within a community, the more output of productivity. I try to be non-biased in my approaches to tasks and that has served me well in collaboration efforts in the professional world. I'm always willing to learn and have an open mind to ideas and criticism. I'm very much a hands-on learner and from watching an example I can generally pick things up step-by-step very quickly. I am both gregarious and focused within the work environment, whenever necessary. I have grant writing capabilities and can read data charts and graphs with ease. Summary I am a senior at Stanford University currently pursuing a B.A. in English. During my four years at Stanford, I have taken diverse and challenging courses in literature, language, philosophy, and art, as well as working part- or full-time whenever possible. My senior year at Stanford has been busy but intensely rewarding as I find myself juggling commitments such as a variety of advanced classes, my honors thesis, and my job as a resident assistant in a freshman dorm.  
 
As a resident assistant at Stanford, it is my responsibility to promote and contribute to a safe, fun, and healthy dorm community for my inspiring and engaging residents. My fellow staff members and I plan and execute small- and large-scale dorm activities, from quarterly dinners to a weekend stay in Lake Tahoe; I also counsel individual residents on emotional and academic issues, which has contributed to what I perceive as my position as a confidant and role model for many of my residents. I take my job very seriously, and it has been a source of tremendous satisfaction and personal and professional growth this year. While at Stanford, I have also worked part-time as a student assistant at the Stanford Law School and as a tutor for the Structured Liberal Education (SLE) program. Additionally, I interned in the marketing division of SAS Institute for four consecutive summers. 
 
As graduation nears, I am interested in and pursuing careers in the fields of publishing, education, media, art, advertising, marketing, and sales. I believe my education in the humanities and my work experience have prepared me for diverse positions in these industries, and I am eager to challenge myself, apply my skills, and contribute to the success of a fine company or organization during this exciting transition.  
 
I would love to hear from prospective employers, recruiters, or anyone working in these fields; new perspectives are always valuable to me, so please contact me if you'd like to connect! Summer Research Scholar SENS Research Foundation June 2014  –  September 2014  (4 months) Mountain View, CA I worked on a project with the LysoSENS team to create a cell model of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) from RNAi-transfected cells for testing of a lysosomal enzyme on rescuing diseased cells. I did tissue culture work with human retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) ARPE-19 cells, and I performed western blotting and immunofluorescent staining to compare expression of key AMD and RPE proteins in aged and non-aged cells. I led bi-monthly presentations of the project goals and progress, drafted research reports, and attended and presented a poster at the SRF “Rejuvenation Biotechnology” conference in Santa Clara, CA.
